PIONEER EXPERIENCE: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A. AIMS OF QUESTIONNAIRE TO THE PERSONS SERVING FOR THIS QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who has lived in Western Canada before 1905 can answer all questions. Some of the questions here will not apply to you, but others may prove impossible for you to answer. If there is not sufficient space, leave blank spaces.

It should be noted that the answers given are not intended for publication purposes, but only for personal use.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who have lived in Western Canada before 1905, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Life: What I Know," was distributed. If you have not already received it, please put a check mark here ( ).

Western Canada Pioneer Registry is still being circulated. If you would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

All questionnaires will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below:

- Pioneer health
- Pioneer social life
- Pioneer sports and recreation
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experiences

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
It is difficult to answer a general questionnaire in pioneer life because no individual who has lived in pioneer times can give an accurate answer to such questions. It is therefore suggested that each person should answer the questions as accurately as possible.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who have lived in Western Canada before 1905, and may be interested in the history of the province or not. If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.
